newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico same-day peso closes 4.6 centavos lower.
newsitem.headline: Mexico same-day peso closes 4.6 centavos lower.

text.p: Mexico's same-day peso closed substantially weaker Monday amid jitters and uncertainty over Tuesday's Fed meeting, traders said.
"The dollar was in heavy demand again. Corporations and banks were covering positions ahead of a possible hike in U.S. interest rates," a trader said.
Same-day peso contracts closed 4.6 centavos lower at 7.58/7.5840 per dollar.
Meanwhile, the benchmark 48-hour peso was down 3.9 at 7.5880/7.5910, with 24-hour contracts 3.4 centavos lower at 7.5830/7.5840.
Traders said they were expecting the Federal Open Market Committee to raise U.S. interest rates by 25 basis points.
"I doubt they will put rates up by more than 25 basis points...growth in the U.S. economy has not been hot enough to fuel a sharp inflationary hike," a local peso trader said.
Traders said the peso was also under pressure from falling share prices in the Mexican stock market.
"Demand for dollars is not yet heavy enough for the peso to weaken to 7.60 per dollar, but if the stock market continues to slide then that could happen," a trader said.
The leading IPC index for Mexican stocks was down 26.76 points, or 0.81 percent, at 3,291.47.
